description.narrative: Enhancing Effectiveness and Financial Sustainability of Protected Area in Malaysia (PA)
first-order administrative division
first-order administrative division
region
Effective sitelevel PA management
Tiger population as a flagship species in target PAs namely Taman Negara EndauRompin National Park and Royal Belum State Park

comment.narrative:
Estimated tiger population for year 2013
Taman Negara 18
EndauRompin National Park XX
Royal Belum State Park XX
Estimated tiger population for the three target PAs for year 2013 will be used as baseline and the baseline figures will be indicated in the next Project Implementation Review 2013 2014
50 increase in tiger population

The official figure made public in 2014 is 250 340 This is based on fieldbased data gathered from seven known tiger ranging areas in Peninsula Malaysia Estimates are based on camera trap surveys and field observation mainly by Wildlife Conservation Society DWNP and WWF Malaysia Taman Negara EndauRompin and Royal Belum among the seven areas studied More studies are needed beyond these areas
In order to obtain a reliable estimate for the whole country it is important that additional forested areas are also studied It remains difficult to estimate tiger population and compare data from previous years A definitive comparison with previous estimates quoted in the baseline figure is not advisable as the previous method of data collection and extrapolation is different
50 increase in tiger population

The official figure made public in 2014 is 250 340 This is based on fieldbased data gathered from seven known tiger ranging areas in Peninsula Malaysia Estimates are based on camera trap surveys and field observation mainly by Wildlife Conservation Society DWNP and WWF Malaysia Taman Negara EndauRompin and Royal Belum among the seven areas studied More studies are needed beyond these areas
In order to obtain a reliable estimate for the whole country it is important that additional forested areas are also studied It remains difficult to estimate tiger population and compare data from previous years A definitive comparison with previous estimates quoted in the baseline figure is not advisable as the previous method of data collection and extrapolation is different

description.narrative: Improved management effectiveness as per METT scores for three target PAs

comment.narrative:
METT scores in 2010
Taman Negara 74
EndauRompin 58
Royal Belum 53

Average 10 increase in METT scores for 3 target PAs
TN 82
ER NP 68
RB 65

METT scores for 2014
Taman Negara NP 745 score 76
EndauRompin NP 598 score 61
Royal Belum SP 667 score 70
The METT score for Taman Negara remained little changed at 745 Generally while the park scored well in terms of professional experience and capacity and having good systems and structure it registered weaker scores associated with having adequate trained staff equipment technology and resources needed for effective management Many tools and assets need to be upgraded to support park management needs This is also in light of the increased threats associated with poaching activity within the park as well as higher risk of encroachment as land use change in converting the landscape surrounding the park from forest to plantations roads and other uses
The METT score for Endau Rompin registered a slight increase The increase reflects some positive developments for capacity building for park staff as well as strengthening research and monitoring via the MoA signed with Universiti Tun Hussein Onn The Strategic Plan Pelan Perancangan Strategik for 20122016 was reviewed in 2014 to and has been useful to strengthen Park management However the Park is hampered by the lack of a detailed Management and Business Plan and park staff are hampered in their ability to implement effective management due to resource and budget constraints The increased exposure of park boundaries roads and waterways to poachers is also an issue requiring urgent attention
Royal Belum SP recorded a higher score of 70 exceeding the project target This mainly reflects the strong institutional support from the state government for setting aside the State Park primarily as a PA for conservation The state and PSPC have put in place the necessary legal and management processes for planning management and reporting and planning however effective management continues to be hampered by lack of human resources for various aspects including enforcement research and monitoring and community engagement

Average 10 increase in METT scores for 3 target PAs
TN 82
ER NP 68
RB 65

METT scores for 2014
Taman Negara NP 745 score 76
EndauRompin NP 598 score 61
Royal Belum SP 667 score 70
The METT score for Taman Negara remained little changed at 745 Generally while the park scored well in terms of professional experience and capacity and having good systems and structure it registered weaker scores associated with having adequate trained staff equipment technology and resources needed for effective management Many tools and assets need to be upgraded to support park management needs This is also in light of the increased threats associated with poaching activity within the park as well as higher risk of encroachment as land use change in converting the landscape surrounding the park from forest to plantations roads and other uses
The METT score for Endau Rompin registered a slight increase The increase reflects some positive developments for capacity building for park staff as well as strengthening research and monitoring via the MoA signed with Universiti Tun Hussein Onn The Strategic Plan Pelan Perancangan Strategik for 20122016 was reviewed in 2014 to and has been useful to strengthen Park management However the Park is hampered by the lack of a detailed Management and Business Plan and park staff are hampered in their ability to implement effective management due to resource and budget constraints The increased exposure of park boundaries roads and waterways to poachers is also an issue requiring urgent attention
Royal Belum SP recorded a higher score of 70 exceeding the project target This mainly reflects the strong institutional support from the state government for setting aside the State Park primarily as a PA for conservation The state and PSPC have put in place the necessary legal and management processes for planning management and reporting and planning however effective management continues to be hampered by lack of human resources for various aspects including enforcement research and monitoring and community engagement

description.narrative: Number of PAs successfully meeting national management criteria and accessing performancebased financial transfers from the Federal system

comment.narrative: No baseline exists

All 3 target PA sites have approved management and business financing plans
20 increase in federal allocation of funding

The development of management and business plan for the three sites commenced since January 2015 Two deliverables have been submitted namely the gap analysis and stocktaking report Standard template is being developed to describe key elements of a PA management and business plan and will be strengthened through stakeholder consultations
Federal allocation for the sites in year 2014 are
Taman Negara MYR 126 million US 394 million
EndauRompin MYR 220 million US 688 million
Royal Belum MYR 165 million US 516 million
Year 2014 exchange rate at US100 MYR320 is used

description.narrative: Increase in gross revenue amount and revenue sources of the three demonstration PAs

comment.narrative:
Taman Negara MYR 350000 from entrance fees and recreational related charges
EndauRompin National Park MYR 999892 from entrance fees tourism and recreational charges income from concessions
Royal Belum State Park MYR 126000 from entrance fees and recreational related charges
20 increase in gross revenue for the 3 target PA sites over the project period

Taman Negara National Park MYR581585 from entrance fees and recreational related charges MYR152577 is revenue from resort concessionaire at Kuala Tahan
EndauRompin National Park MYR820955 from entrance fees tourism and recreational charges income from concessions
Royal Belum State Park MYR310000 from entrance fees and recreational related charges
Taman Negara National Park increased its collection in conjunction with the 75th Anniversary of the establishment of the Park However these gains were undercut by the impact of serious flooding which occurred in December 2014 The Project also produced a commemorative video and participated in an exhibition to help rekindle public interest in the Park
Both Endau Rompin National Park and Royal Belum State Park were affected by the December floods which continues to affect visitors in 2015 Despite this Royal Belum still managed to generate more than double its 2014 collection compared to the baseline It has also recorded steady visitor arrivals from European visitors due to promotion strategies abroad Endau Rompin NP recorded fewer visitor arrivals compared to the baseline The park recently doubled its visitor fees for nonMalaysians however the impact of this is not evident as currently Malaysians form the majority of the visitors to this park
Taman Negara has plan to introduce a new fee structure This is currently under the consideration of State Government of Pahang but the quantum and timeline for new structure is yet to be finalized A revised fee structure was introduced at EndauRompin in 2013 which has a two tier fee rates for locals and foreigners There are no plans yet for Royal Belum
20 increase in gross revenue for the 3 target PA sites over the project period

Taman Negara National Park MYR581585 from entrance fees and recreational related charges MYR152577 is revenue from resort concessionaire at Kuala Tahan
EndauRompin National Park MYR820955 from entrance fees tourism and recreational charges income from concessions
Royal Belum State Park MYR310000 from entrance fees and recreational related charges
Taman Negara National Park increased its collection in conjunction with the 75th Anniversary of the establishment of the Park However these gains were undercut by the impact of serious flooding which occurred in December 2014 The Project also produced a commemorative video and participated in an exhibition to help rekindle public interest in the Park
Both Endau Rompin National Park and Royal Belum State Park were affected by the December floods which continues to affect visitors in 2015 Despite this Royal Belum still managed to generate more than double its 2014 collection compared to the baseline It has also recorded steady visitor arrivals from European visitors due to promotion strategies abroad Endau Rompin NP recorded fewer visitor arrivals compared to the baseline The park recently doubled its visitor fees for nonMalaysians however the impact of this is not evident as currently Malaysians form the majority of the visitors to this park
Taman Negara has plan to introduce a new fee structure This is currently under the consideration of State Government of Pahang but the quantum and timeline for new structure is yet to be finalized A revised fee structure was introduced at EndauRompin in 2013 which has a two tier fee rates for locals and foreigners There are no plans yet for Royal Belum

description.narrative:
Length of park patrolled per year
Number of patrolling programmes per year
Percentage of the area patrolled per year
Number of patrolling staff
Number of illegal activity including encroachment and poaching cases within PA reported

comment.narrative:
Taman Negara 5 10 km per day
Taman Negara 8 10 days per month by walking
Taman Negara 10
Taman Negara 2 cases in 2010

25 increase
50 increase
25 increase
50 increase

In 2014 in addition to its regular patrols in Taman Negara DWNP carried out 6 joint patrols with Malaysian Armed Forces under the 1MBEON 1Malaysia Biodiversity Enforcement Operation Network Programme spearheaded by the governments National Blue Ocean Strategy NBOS NBOS is a federal government approach to formulate highimpact lowcost national strategies that are able to be rapidly executed often combining and reallocating existing resources and capacitiesThe funds received by DWNP for this programme in 2014 was MYR570000
A total of 636 personnel were involved in these patrols comprising 252 staff and 384 Army personnel
Area covered in Taman Negara NP 143300 Ha or 33 of the total park area
A total of 19 poachers were arrested and charged Encroachment activities in the boundary of the Park were uncovered and halted
The 1MBEON programme will continue in 2015 and will include Endau Rompin NP 3 joint patrols and Royal Belum NP 3 joint patrols There will again be six programmes in Taman Negara NP focussing on hotspot areas

25 increase
50 increase
25 increase
50 increase

In 2014 in addition to its regular patrols in Taman Negara DWNP carried out 6 joint patrols with Malaysian Armed Forces under the 1MBEON 1Malaysia Biodiversity Enforcement Operation Network Programme spearheaded by the governments National Blue Ocean Strategy NBOS NBOS is a federal government approach to formulate highimpact lowcost national strategies that are able to be rapidly executed often combining and reallocating existing resources and capacitiesThe funds received by DWNP for this programme in 2014 was MYR570000
A total of 636 personnel were involved in these patrols comprising 252 staff and 384 Army personnel
Area covered in Taman Negara NP 143300 Ha or 33 of the total park area
A total of 19 poachers were arrested and charged Encroachment activities in the boundary of the Park were uncovered and halted
The 1MBEON programme will continue in 2015 and will include Endau Rompin NP 3 joint patrols and Royal Belum NP 3 joint patrols There will again be six programmes in Taman Negara NP focussing on hotspot areas

description.narrative: Systemic Institutional Capacities to manage and financially support a national PA System
Integrated PA information and performance monitoring system

comment.narrative: Neither performance criteria nor monitoring systems specific to PA management exist
A national integrated PA information system established with the primary function of PA performance monitoring and decision support for relevant government bodies

Data on PAs is fragmented and dispersed the project has been identifying the best agency to host the database Initial consultation with the Forest Institute of Malaysia FRIM which is responsible for updating and maintaining the National Biodiversity Clearing House Mechanism established in 2008 indicates their support for hosting a PA database within the CHMs Biodiversity Database which can support decisionmaking in the planning and management of PA It is envisaged that the CHM can serve as an accessible and userfriendly platform for housing information on PAs in the country
As an interim measure the project is developing a PA profile template that captures essential managementoriented data and information of three target PA sites and PAs within the three PA Networks Having demonstrated the usefulness of this template for gathering and collating data on PAs the project will seek cooperation of relevant PA agencies to complete the actual database which will ultimately resides with FRIM
A national integrated PA information system established with the primary function of PA performance monitoring and decision support for relevant government bodies

Data on PAs is fragmented and dispersed the project has been identifying the best agency to host the database Initial consultation with the Forest Institute of Malaysia FRIM which is responsible for updating and maintaining the National Biodiversity Clearing House Mechanism established in 2008 indicates their support for hosting a PA database within the CHMs Biodiversity Database which can support decisionmaking in the planning and management of PA It is envisaged that the CHM can serve as an accessible and userfriendly platform for housing information on PAs in the country
As an interim measure the project is developing a PA profile template that captures essential managementoriented data and information of three target PA sites and PAs within the three PA Networks Having demonstrated the usefulness of this template for gathering and collating data on PAs the project will seek cooperation of relevant PA agencies to complete the actual database which will ultimately resides with FRIM

description.narrative:
National PA System mainstreamed in the budgeting process for 5year Malaysia Plan
Increased number of bankable projects in support of PA management approved for funding through operational grants

comment.narrative: No budget line for PA management in Malaysia Plan Currently the budgets for PA infrastructure development is determined based on individual requests from State governments with no systematic planning looking at conservation priorities of the national PA network as a whole

Dedicated PA budget line in Malaysia Plan
Budgeting process of PA managementdevelopment is conducted based on increased levels of conservation priorities within the Federal and State funding system using a range of tools including economic valuation results

The 11th Malaysia Plan 2016 2020 the 5year development plan was launched in May 2015 with six strategic thrusts where Strategic Thrust 4 Pursuing Green Growth for Sustainability and Resilience has identified conservation of protected areas as one of the focus areas Focus Area C Strategy C1 The Focus Area A also includes a strategy on sustainable financing mechanisms such as green tax carbon tax REDD etc Please refer to uploaded file on 11th Malaysia Plan and Strategy Paper 12
The NRE provided its inputs into the 11th Malaysia Plan through the submission of a draft strategy paper on biodiversity and environmental management of project proposals for consideration under the 11th Malaysia Plan Each of the three focal sites and their respective PA agencies have applied for budget allocations under the 11th Malaysia Plan
There is no dedicated budget line for PA in 11th Malaysia Plan The main criteria for all project selection including PA related projects is Creativity Index where proposed projects need to demonstrate low cost and high impacts to income cost of living simplicity and convenience health safety security harmony recreation and national pride and environmental sustainability

Dedicated PA budget line in Malaysia Plan
Budgeting process of PA managementdevelopment is conducted based on increased levels of conservation priorities within the Federal and State funding system using a range of tools including economic valuation results

The 11th Malaysia Plan 2016 2020 the 5year development plan was launched in May 2015 with six strategic thrusts where Strategic Thrust 4 Pursuing Green Growth for Sustainability and Resilience has identified conservation of protected areas as one of the focus areas Focus Area C Strategy C1 The Focus Area A also includes a strategy on sustainable financing mechanisms such as green tax carbon tax REDD etc Please refer to uploaded file on 11th Malaysia Plan and Strategy Paper 12
The NRE provided its inputs into the 11th Malaysia Plan through the submission of a draft strategy paper on biodiversity and environmental management of project proposals for consideration under the 11th Malaysia Plan Each of the three focal sites and their respective PA agencies have applied for budget allocations under the 11th Malaysia Plan
There is no dedicated budget line for PA in 11th Malaysia Plan The main criteria for all project selection including PA related projects is Creativity Index where proposed projects need to demonstrate low cost and high impacts to income cost of living simplicity and convenience health safety security harmony recreation and national pride and environmental sustainability

description.narrative: Establishment of the policy framework for the National PA system

comment.narrative: No framework exists resulting in a fragmented PA system with a large number of PAs gazetted under different acts based on varied management standards
A single framework with clear categorisation of all the PAs in the PA Master List in Peninsular Malaysia with uniform accepted management standards and reporting requirements

The project has improvised the initial plan of using PoWPA Action Plan as a platform to develop the National Framework for PA due to the process of finalizing the PoWPA Action Plan led by the Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment NRE is still ongoing and yet to reach consensus among the key federal and state agencies
The project has since taken a proactive approach by carried out consultations with key state governments including Sabah and Sarawak where some States have agreed in principle to develop a common National Framework standard definition and management practices for PAs A draft Terms of Reference TOR for national experts was initially developed in March 2015 Following consultation with DWNP and UNDP the decision was made to engage two national experts to focus on two key areas i Legal and Enabling Environment for Establishing a National Framework and ii Basis and outline for the National Framework The TORs have been prepared and they are now being finalized for advertisement in September 2015 It is expected that the National Framework to complete by end of 2016
The ongoing preparation of the Management and Business Plans for the three target PA sites also contributes to the development of National Framework for PA by drafting a common management and business plan template which could form the basis of a common template for nationwide adoption Key agencies will be invited to give their inputs to the prototype template to ensure its applicability in different PA contexts across the country
A single framework with clear categorisation of all the PAs in the PA Master List in Peninsular Malaysia with uniform accepted management standards and reporting requirements

The project has improvised the initial plan of using PoWPA Action Plan as a platform to develop the National Framework for PA due to the process of finalizing the PoWPA Action Plan led by the Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment NRE is still ongoing and yet to reach consensus among the key federal and state agencies
The project has since taken a proactive approach by carried out consultations with key state governments including Sabah and Sarawak where some States have agreed in principle to develop a common National Framework standard definition and management practices for PAs A draft Terms of Reference TOR for national experts was initially developed in March 2015 Following consultation with DWNP and UNDP the decision was made to engage two national experts to focus on two key areas i Legal and Enabling Environment for Establishing a National Framework and ii Basis and outline for the National Framework The TORs have been prepared and they are now being finalized for advertisement in September 2015 It is expected that the National Framework to complete by end of 2016
The ongoing preparation of the Management and Business Plans for the three target PA sites also contributes to the development of National Framework for PA by drafting a common management and business plan template which could form the basis of a common template for nationwide adoption Key agencies will be invited to give their inputs to the prototype template to ensure its applicability in different PA contexts across the country

description.narrative: Financial incentive system based primarily on performance indices established and operational

comment.narrative: No performancelinked financial incentive system exists
System established supporting a minimum of 866000 ha of the PA estate

The establishment of the National Natural Resources Conservation Trust in 2014 provides an opportunity to pilot the performancebased financing system for protected areas As such the project has developed governance structure and drafted the operating guidelines for the National Natural Resources Conservation Trust Fund NCTF and submitted to the Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment NRE
The draft Operating Guidelines include general criteria for project selection appropriate indicators and ME system but it does not specify PA related performance indicators for PA related projectsinitiatives
The Operating Guidelines were tabled at the first meeting of the NCTF Board held on 21 April 2015 There has been limited feedback received from NRE regarding the performance indicators for PA related project selection under the NCTF
System established supporting a minimum of 866000 ha of the PA estate

The establishment of the National Natural Resources Conservation Trust in 2014 provides an opportunity to pilot the performancebased financing system for protected areas As such the project has developed governance structure and drafted the operating guidelines for the National Natural Resources Conservation Trust Fund NCTF and submitted to the Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment NRE
The draft Operating Guidelines include general criteria for project selection appropriate indicators and ME system but it does not specify PA related performance indicators for PA related projectsinitiatives
The Operating Guidelines were tabled at the first meeting of the NCTF Board held on 21 April 2015 There has been limited feedback received from NRE regarding the performance indicators for PA related project selection under the NCTF

description.narrative: Technical and institutional capacities to manage subnational PA networks including capacities for effective financial management

Increase in capacity development indicator score for three target subnational PA networks
DWNP
JNPC
PSPC

comment.narrative:
Average 54
61
61
45

An average gt10 increase of the capacity development indicator score for each target subnational PA networks
70
70
55

Capacity scorecards for the three target subnational PA networks was reviewed between March and May 2015 The scores obtained were as follows
DWNP 635
JNPC 635
PSPC 552
JNPCs improved scores is mainly due to the following areas
1 Strengthened legal capacity for enforcement arising from the revision of JNPC Enactment
2 A total of 39 permanent posts had been approved for JNPC in 2014 As a result 39 contract and daily paid staff will be upgraded to permanent positions in 2015 This is a significant development for ensuring job security and strengthening prospects for career development of protected area personnel
PSPC has exceeded the end of project target level Main improvements are stemmed from actions taken to strengthen the State Park Enactment to improve enforcement and penalties In addition cooperation between PSPC and other agencies DWNP State Forestry Department and the Royal Army Force through the 1MBEON has helped to strengthen the enforcement operations of PAs Efforts are being made to increase the number of staff positions in PSPC
An Integrated Management Plan has been prepared by NCIA in 2012 covering 10 years It covers some macrolevel planning aspects for PSPC and has placed emphasis on Perak establishing itself as a major destination for ecotourism with Royal Belum being the jewel in the crown of its PA network These developments are anticipated to lend support for the need to professionalise and strengthen effective management of the park There is a stronger basis now to set a higher target for the remainder of the project period

An average gt10 increase of the capacity development indicator score for each target subnational PA networks
70
70
55

An Integrated Management Plan has been prepared by NCIA in 2012 covering 10 years It covers some macrolevel planning aspects for PSPC and has placed emphasis on Perak establishing itself as a major destination for ecotourism with Royal Belum being the jewel in the crown of its PA network These developments are anticipated to lend support for the need to professionalise and strengthen effective management of the park There is a stronger basis now to set a higher target for the remainder of the project period

description.narrative: Financing gap decreased by at least 25 in the target PA subnetworks PSPC DWNP

comment.narrative:
Current financing gaps based on regional benchmark of 196 staff per 1000 km and US 1000 per km are
DWNP MYR869 million US290 million
PSPC MYR212 million US071 million
An average 25 decrease in the financing gaps of the 3 PA sub network agencies in real terms through operationalisation of financial management and revenue diversification models across the sites

The business plans currently being developed with the project support will help to project the financial and capacity gaps at Taman Negara EndauRompin and Royal Belum within Malaysian context Efforts also being planned to undertake financial planning analysis at PA Networks level together with TEEB analysis All the three PA Networks registered notable increase in year 2014 operating budget allocation compared to 2013
The financing gaps are
DWNP US548 million 22 reduction from 2012 level
PSPC US178 million 2 decrease from 2012 level
In terms of development budget in 2014 both networks PSPC and JNPC received additional allocation from the Federal Government for ecotourism related infrastructure development
An average 25 decrease in the financing gaps of the 3 PA sub network agencies in real terms through operationalisation of financial management and revenue diversification models across the sites

The business plans currently being developed with the project support will help to project the financial and capacity gaps at Taman Negara EndauRompin and Royal Belum within Malaysian context Efforts also being planned to undertake financial planning analysis at PA Networks level together with TEEB analysis All the three PA Networks registered notable increase in year 2014 operating budget allocation compared to 2013
The financing gaps are
DWNP US548 million 22 reduction from 2012 level
PSPC US178 million 2 decrease from 2012 level
In terms of development budget in 2014 both networks PSPC and JNPC received additional allocation from the Federal Government for ecotourism related infrastructure development

description.narrative: Coordination between the subPA network agencies

comment.narrative: Minimal coordination mechanisms
Three agencies have common management approaches PA performance monitoring mechanisms and capacity development programmes

A stronger basis for standardizing approaches for PA management is being advanced through the projects initiatives to build support for a common National Framework for PAs In addition these aspects are also expected to be enhanced through the development of a standard template for the PA management and business plan
Through the transformation programme being implemented for the IBD by October 2015 there will be a common national training platform for personnel from PA agencies In addition the project continues to facilitate training and exposure opportunities such as participation in the Korea Friendship Park Programme 2 participants July 2015 and support for additional participants in the Advanced Training Course at the Wildlife Institute of India Nov 2015
To enhance coordination with PA agencies and state governments the project coordinators at the state level are playing an active role and enabling the project to respond to needs identified by PA agencies For 2015 an Interpretative Skills course has been developed for staff and local community at Endau Rompin National Park while a learning and exchange activity is being planned for staff government officers and community representatives from Taman Negara National Park
Three agencies have common management approaches PA performance monitoring mechanisms and capacity development programmes

A stronger basis for standardizing approaches for PA management is being advanced through the projects initiatives to build support for a common National Framework for PAs In addition these aspects are also expected to be enhanced through the development of a standard template for the PA management and business plan
Through the transformation programme being implemented for the IBD by October 2015 there will be a common national training platform for personnel from PA agencies In addition the project continues to facilitate training and exposure opportunities such as participation in the Korea Friendship Park Programme 2 participants July 2015 and support for additional participants in the Advanced Training Course at the Wildlife Institute of India Nov 2015
To enhance coordination with PA agencies and state governments the project coordinators at the state level are playing an active role and enabling the project to respond to needs identified by PA agencies For 2015 an Interpretative Skills course has been developed for staff and local community at Endau Rompin National Park while a learning and exchange activity is being planned for staff government officers and community representatives from Taman Negara National Park

description.narrative: Number of PAs successfully meeting national management criteria and accessing performancebased financial transfers from the Federal system

comment.narrative: No baseline exists
At least eight 8 among the terrestrial PAs over 20000 ha under DWNP JNPC and PSPC

The national management criteria for performancebased financial transfers from federal to subnational is yet to be established It is expected to be pilot tested through the implementation of National Natural Resources Conservation Trust Fund by end of 2015 Application of performance monitoring and evaluation mechanism will be part of Trust Fund operationalization process In addition the development of management plans for the three target sites will provide important feedback to establishing the basis for national management criteria
At least eight 8 among the terrestrial PAs over 20000 ha under DWNP JNPC and PSPC

The national management criteria for performancebased financial transfers from federal to subnational is yet to be established It is expected to be pilot tested through the implementation of National Natural Resources Conservation Trust Fund by end of 2015 Application of performance monitoring and evaluation mechanism will be part of Trust Fund operationalization process In addition the development of management plans for the three target sites will provide important feedback to establishing the basis for national management criteria

description.narrative: Economic and financial planning capacity institutionalized in the three subnational PA network agencies

comment.narrative: There is minimal human capacity or institutional structure to address issues of financial sustainability
A unit is established in each of the subnational PA agency dedicated to revenue diversification that will ensure financial sustainability

In consultation with the three PA agencies the project has ascertained that all agencies already have specific units in place that are responsible for financial planning In view of this it was recommended that the focus of the PA Financing project should be to enhance the skills for sustainable financial planning within these units Current practices are mainly based on government budgetary allocations and there is limited focus at present on diversification of funding sources and ensuring performancebased financing All Federal Ministries and agencies are expected to apply outcomebased budgeting in 20162017 onward
The business plan development is expected to provide guidance and best practices to PA networks on potential mechanisms and modality for revenue diversification and sustainable financing mechanisms
A unit is established in each of the subnational PA agency dedicated to revenue diversification that will ensure financial sustainability

In consultation with the three PA agencies the project has ascertained that all agencies already have specific units in place that are responsible for financial planning In view of this it was recommended that the focus of the PA Financing project should be to enhance the skills for sustainable financial planning within these units Current practices are mainly based on government budgetary allocations and there is limited focus at present on diversification of funding sources and ensuring performancebased financing All Federal Ministries and agencies are expected to apply outcomebased budgeting in 20162017 onward
The business plan development is expected to provide guidance and best practices to PA networks on potential mechanisms and modality for revenue diversification and sustainable financing mechanisms

description.narrative: To establish a performancebased financing structure to support effective Protected Area PA system management in Peninsular Malaysia

Financial sustainability scorecard for the 3 PA networks
DWNP
JNPC
PSPC

comment.narrative:
DWNP 558
JNPC 447
PSPC 531
Financial sustainability scorecards were completed in consultation with the three PA agencies and other key subnational authorities in March and May 2015 Preliminary results were collated and shared with the agencies highlighting the need for supplementary data Follow up meetings were held with each of the agencies to confirm and verify the final scores
The financial sustainability scores for DWNP JNPC and PSPC have recorded an increase with PSPC exceeded the target level at end of project 50 Part I of the financial sustainability scorecard reflects a gradual increase in budget allocation of the three PA networks In 2014 all the PA networks benefitted from substantial increase in development budget allocation mainly for the development of infrastructure beneficial to PA management such as roads Endau Rompin a jetty Royal Belum and other upkeep and maintenance works DWNP As these are oneoff allocation the figures can only be matched with PA networks continue to advocate for additional development budget through submission and approval of PA related project proposals that are in line with the development priorities of the 11th Malaysia Plan
In terms of revenue generated from the PAs Taman Negara National Park had a strong year buoyed by recognition of the 75th Anniversary of the Parks establishment However a devastating flood in the last quarter of 2014 in the park closure resulted in low visitor numbers from November 2014 to March 2015 Royal Belum State Park has demonstrated increased capacity to generate more revenue from visitors Despide of the serious flooding experienced in December 2014 the Parks collection from entrance fees and recreational related charges was more than double the 2010 baseline It has recorded steady visitor arrivals from Europe due to successful promotion in these highvalue niche markets thereby increasing revenue from tourism while upholding strong emphasis on conservation PSPCs higher score can be attributed to significant improvements in Part II which is a measure of capacity development for financial management and planning This is a result of better understanding of the financial planning and management system in place which includes technical support from the Perak State Government Adjustments were made to the Total Possible Score as several provisions were technically not applicable this includes some of the revenue diversification mechanisms which are currently not available and feasible As the financial score for PSPC exceeds the end of project target level it is recommended that a new target be set to provide scope for further improvement and benchmarking
Overall both JNPC and DWNP showed stronger financial sustainability scores edging closer to the end of project target level These stronger scores are also mainly attributed to improved scores in Part IIIn demonstrating improved capacity in planning and financial management DWNP for example has improved its financial data management to more accurately represent actual expenditure of PA management across the different states which was previously bundled with wildlife management costs
All three PA agencies have much room for improvement in terms of enhancing their scores in Part III which deals with tools for revenue generation by PAs Of the three JNPC has made some progress towards diversifying its sources of revenue a new Private Public Partnership PPP initiative at Pulau Kukup involving Iskandar Regional Development Authority and JNPC is currently being developed If successful this could present a new source of revenue for the JNPCs PA network

DWNP 558
JNPC 447
PSPC 531
Financial sustainability scorecards were completed in consultation with the three PA agencies and other key subnational authorities in March and May 2015 Preliminary results were collated and shared with the agencies highlighting the need for supplementary data Follow up meetings were held with each of the agencies to confirm and verify the final scores
The financial sustainability scores for DWNP JNPC and PSPC have recorded an increase with PSPC exceeded the target level at end of project 50 Part I of the financial sustainability scorecard reflects a gradual increase in budget allocation of the three PA networks In 2014 all the PA networks benefitted from substantial increase in development budget allocation mainly for the development of infrastructure beneficial to PA management such as roads Endau Rompin a jetty Royal Belum and other upkeep and maintenance works DWNP As these are oneoff allocation the figures can only be matched with PA networks continue to advocate for additional development budget through submission and approval of PA related project proposals that are in line with the development priorities of the 11th Malaysia Plan
In terms of revenue generated from the PAs Taman Negara National Park had a strong year buoyed by recognition of the 75th Anniversary of the Parks establishment However a devastating flood in the last quarter of 2014 in the park closure resulted in low visitor numbers from November 2014 to March 2015 Royal Belum State Park has demonstrated increased capacity to generate more revenue from visitors Despide of the serious flooding experienced in December 2014 the Parks collection from entrance fees and recreational related charges was more than double the 2010 baseline It has recorded steady visitor arrivals from Europe due to successful promotion in these highvalue niche markets thereby increasing revenue from tourism while upholding strong emphasis on conservation PSPCs higher score can be attributed to significant improvements in Part II which is a measure of capacity development for financial management and planning This is a result of better understanding of the financial planning and management system in place which includes technical support from the Perak State Government Adjustments were made to the Total Possible Score as several provisions were technically not applicable this includes some of the revenue diversification mechanisms which are currently not available and feasible As the financial score for PSPC exceeds the end of project target level it is recommended that a new target be set to provide scope for further improvement and benchmarking
Overall both JNPC and DWNP showed stronger financial sustainability scores edging closer to the end of project target level These stronger scores are also mainly attributed to improved scores in Part IIIn demonstrating improved capacity in planning and financial management DWNP for example has improved its financial data management to more accurately represent actual expenditure of PA management across the different states which was previously bundled with wildlife management costs
All three PA agencies have much room for improvement in terms of enhancing their scores in Part III which deals with tools for revenue generation by PAs Of the three JNPC has made some progress towards diversifying its sources of revenue a new Private Public Partnership PPP initiative at Pulau Kukup involving Iskandar Regional Development Authority and JNPC is currently being developed If successful this could present a new source of revenue for the JNPCs PA network

description.narrative: Increase in the Federal Government investment in PA management

comment.narrative:
USD 725 million in 2010 for the DWNP JNPC and PSPC
USD 6 million in 20112012 development budget under 10th Malaysia Plan

25 increase of operational budget in real terms for the 3 target PA networks based on aggregate funding from Federal and State Government source
25 increase in development budget under the 5year Malaysia Plan

Operating Budget The total operating budget for the three PA networks for 2014 was US1087 million MYR350 million a 50 increase compared to the 2010 baseline at US725 million The breakdown of operating budget of each PA network as follows
Department of Wildlife and National Park DWNP US769 million MYR2460 million
Johor National Park Corporation JNPC US250 million MYR80 million
Perak State Park Corporation PSPC US056 million MYR18 million
Development Budget In 2014 the total development budget allocated was US17 million MYR545 million a 183 increase from baseline level of US6 million The surge is mainly due to the implementation of infrastructure development projects such as wildlife crossing bridgeunderpass wildlife conservation centres and jetty habitat enrichment wildlife survey and inventory and wildlife conservation which have been earmarked since year 2011 and 2013 the first and second rolling plan of the 10th Malaysia Plan The breakdown of development budget of each PA network as follows
DWNP US5 million MYR16 million
JNPC US69 million MYR22 million
PSPC US51 million MYR165 million
Year 2014 exchange rate at US100 MYR320 is used to make comparable budget trends instead of current exchange rate which has seen Ringgit Malaysia depreciated significantly against US Dollar
This positive trend reflected an increased government commitment in protected area under the business as usual scenario as the performancebased financing structure for protected area is yet to be established piloted and institutionalized within the existing public finance and budgetary system

description.narrative: 1. Increase in the Government of Malaysia's investment in PA management operation. 2. Financial sustainability scorecard for the 3 PA networks, which are DWNP, JNPC and PSPC. 3. Capacity development scorecard for the 3 PA networks, which are DWNP, JNPC and PSPC. 4. METT score for Taman Negara, Endau-Rompin and Royal Belum State Park

comment.narrative: 1a. USD 7.25 million in 2010 operating budget for the three protected area agencies, which are Department of Wildlife and National Parks (DWNP), Johor National Park Corporation (JNPC) and Perak State Park Corporation (PSPC). 1b. USD 6 million for three protected area networks namely, DWNP, JNPC and PSPC in 2011-2012 development budget under the 10th Malaysia Plan. 2. Financial sustainability scores for the 3 PA networks in 2010: DWNP (49.8%), JNPC (44.4%) and PSPC (40.0%). 3. Capacity development indicator score for the 3 PA networks in 2010: : DWNP (61%), JNPC (61%) and PSPC (45%). 4. Management Effectiveness Tracking Tool (METT) score in 2010: Taman Negara National Park (74), Endau-Rompin National Park (58) and Royal Belum State Park (53).

1. National PA Master List is finalized and adopted by end of Q1 2019. 2. Strategic Plan to restructure National Conservation Ttrust Fund (NCTF) and Resource Mobilization Strategy developed and delivered to KATS by end of 2019. 3. Protected Area Master List to be endorsed and adopted by end of Q1 2019. 4. Business Plans for the 3 Parks (Royal Belum State Park, Endaru Rompin National Park and Taman Negara) developed. 5. TEEB advertisement to be advertised and the survey to start by mid 2019.

1. In a special NSC meeting held on 14 Feb 2019, IP formally adopted the modified National Framework for Protected Area after some in-depth deliberation including consultation. 2. Strategic Plan to restructure National Conservation Ttrust Fund (NCTF) and Resource Mobilization Strategy delivered to KATS by end of 2019. 3. The Protected Area Master List was approved in the Special NSC meeting held on 14 Feb 2019. 4. Business Plans developed and endorsed by DWNP; JNPC and PSPC. Further sessions will be conducted in Q4 2019, to explore implementation potentials of the solutions recommended in the Business Plans. 5. Consultants to implement TEEB study was recruited in September 2019 and the survey is expected to start in October/November 2019
1. Conduct Terminal Evaluation mission by first quarter of 2020 2. Project preparing towards operational closure by 3 June 2020.
1. Project Terminal Evaluation and Final Workshop was conducted on 19 November 2020. 2. Project was operationally closed in July 2020 and financially closed by 31 December 2020.
Not applicable.
Not applicable.
